pageMeta.description: Emissions of greenhouse gases (GHGs) from human activities disturb the radiative energy balance of the earth-atmosphere system. They exacerbate the natural greenhouse effect, leading to temperature changes and other disruption of the earth's climate. Land use changes and forestry also play a role by altering the amount of greenhouse gases captured or released by carbon sinks

content.value: Climate change adaptation - Impacts and risks

Climate change generates significant impacts on the environment, the economy and human welfare. Some impacts will gradually affect economic processes, such as those associated with the effect of rising temperatures, while others may be more acute and periodic such as the increased intensity and the frequency of occurrence of climate-related hazards.

Climate-related hazards put populations and economic assets at risk through increased frequency and intensity of hot temperature extremes, marine heatwaves, heavy precipitation, droughts, intense tropical cyclones and reductions in Arctic Sea ice, snow cover and permafrost. Further threats include wildfires, coastal floods, and sea-level rises (IPCC, 2021).

These compound effects negatively affect economies and contribute to increased socio-economic inequalities. One study shows global GDP could be reduced by as much as 4% in 2050 due to climate change and that lower-income and lower‑middle income countries are more likely face economic losses (World Economic Forum, 2022). The costs from natural disasters alone are estimated at USD 280 billion in 2021, representing approximately 0.29% of global GDP (Munich RE, 2022).

Climate change impacts are especially acute in the LAC region where economic and social vulnerability are compounded by a very close social and economic relationship with the environment. thirteen of the 50 countries most affected by climate change worldwide are in the region (German Watch, 2021). Around 18% of the 11 072 climate‑related extreme weather events registered worldwide between 1970 and 2019 occurred in LAC (WMO, 2021). Warming temperatures, extreme precipitation events leading to floods, landslides and droughts, sea level rise, coastal erosion, ocean and lake acidification resulting in coral bleaching, and storm surges are expected to increase in frequency and severity, with adverse socio‑economic consequences on the region (OECD, 2022). An average of 17 hurricanes per year and 23 category‑5 hurricanes were recorded between 2000 and 2019, mostly affecting Caribbean and Central American countries (OCHA, 2020).
Adaptation is the process of adjustment to actual or expected climate and its effects. In human systems, adaptation seeks to

moderate or avoid harm or exploit beneficial opportunities. In some natural systems, human intervention may facilitate adjustment to expected climate and its effects, for example by the reforestation of native plants or reintroducing a relevant species such as bees.
Both natural and human systems adjust or react to climate change, adaptation as a policy response refers to the explicit human actions, such as investing in produced and natural assets, that have the
intent to reduce the impact of climate change. Further, it may involve restoring natural systems to enhance or recover ecosystem services associated with climate change process
Climate change impacts can generate considerable losses from both extreme events (such as hurricanes)
slow onset events (such as the sea level rise).
and later recovering the environmental and/or physical assets that have been lost or degraded

enormous costs. For example, in the Dominican Republic, the heavy rains of 2016 generated severe economic losses in crops such as plantain, cassava and sweet potato. During the hurricane season of 2017, an estimated loss of USD 52 million was recorded due to lower touristic activity. In the case of Haiti and Puerto Rico, two of the three most affected countries in the world between 1999 and 2018, annual GDP losses reached 2.4% and 3.8%, respectively (OECD, 2022).

Similar economic costs can be caused by the concentration of multiple non‑extreme events in a short period, especially when there are conditions of high exposure and vulnerability in the country. Many countries in LAC are experiencing a fall in agricultural productivity and tourism, as well as climate‑driven migration and high reconstruction costs after natural disasters.

Natural disasters increase expenditures and thus have direct impacts on fiscal deficits and public revenues, affecting the long-term fiscal sustainability of governments. On average, a natural disaster results in costs of 0.8% and 1.1% of GDP, for lower middle‑income and low‑income countries respectively (OECD, 2022).
capacity to deal with the increasing impacts of climate change is limited.

The costs of inaction may be even higher. In the case of the Caribbean, the annual cost of inaction to deal with the effects of sea level rise is estimated to reach USD 22 billion per year by 2050 (10% of GDP) and USD 46 billion by 2100 (22% of GDP) (OECD, 2022). If environmental degradation is not addressed soon, LAC governments will have to add the costs of climate change to those of social vulnerability that could have unprecedented economic and social consequences.

To track the most significant impacts of climate change, the OECD has developed a new set of indicators to monitor climate-related hazards and exposure to these hazards (Maes et al., 2022). The indicator set is based on the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change’s (IPCC) conceptualisation of climate risk, which considers climate-related hazard, exposure, and vulnerability as the key dimensions of disaster risk (Figure 12).

Climate-related hazard is a “potentially damaging climate-related physical event, phenomenon, or human activity that may cause the loss of life or injury, property damage, social and economic disruption or environmental degradation” (UNDRR, 2020). Climate-related hazards can include both sudden onset hazards (i.e. event-driven hazards such as heatwaves or cyclones) and slow onset hazards (i.e. long-term changes in the mean and variability of climate patterns such as mean precipitation or temperature).

The following indicators can support LAC countries to understand the impact of climate-related hazards by assessing the exposure of people and assets to these hazards. It focuses on seven hazard types: (1) extreme temperature, (2) extreme precipitation, (3) drought, (4) wildfire, (5) wind threats, (6) river flooding and (7) coastal flooding. These are key natural hazards, influenced by climate change, with important impacts on people and assets

Figure 13 presents a summary of the sum of hazards identified for a specific geographical area. It can be considered as a map of climate-related hazard “hotspots” where countries need to be concerned with developing integral adaptation and recovery and emergency actions, since they represent areas potentially affected by critical or extreme events.

Over the past decades, population exposure in the LAC region to heat stress has increased significantly. This is alarming for at least two reasons: the potential impact this will have on human health and the economic costs involved in dealing with it.

In the last 40 years, LAC countries have experienced an increase in surface temperature of around 0.6°C. This average varies considerably from a lower bound average temperature increase in countries such as Uruguay of 0.29°C, to an average increase of over 1°C in Belize and Guatemala (Figure 14).
In 2021, on average, 9% of the population in LAC countries were exposed to more than 2 weeks of hot summer days (measured as a daily maximum temperature above 35

), an increase of 3% compared to 1979. This average, however, masks important national variations: Paraguay, for example, has nearly 90% of its population exposed to more than 2 weeks of hot summer days, compared to only 28% in 1979 (Figure 15). For tropical countries, the high temperatures are best represented by the prevalence of tropical nights. In 2021, 77% of the national population was exposed to at least 2 weeks of tropical nights (measured as a minimum temperature above 20 °C) (Figure 16).

Increasing temperatures combined with extreme rainfall events means countries dependent on agriculture production may be vulnerable. This is especially relevant in the case of the LAC region.
Many LAC countries are experiencing an increase in extreme precipitation
, this is a hazard that can trigger the destruction of crops, landslides, or other extreme events

On average, LAC countries have 6.9% of their cropland exposed to more than one week of extreme precipitation (when precipitation exceeds the 99th percentile of the reference period 1981-2010), an increase from 5.2% since 2000. For some countries the change has been much more dramatic. Suriname, Guyana, and Trinidad and Tobago have 64%, 58%, and 28%, of their cropland exposed to more than one week of extreme precipitation, a significant increase compared to 9%, 15%, and 23% respectively in 2000 (Figure 17), this poses a serious risk to food security.

For many years the South America has been affected by severe levels of drought and decreasing water availability. In Central America, water availability per capita is projected to decrease by at least 82% in 2100 while total rainfall is expected to decrease by 11% in 2010 (ECLAC, 2010). These trends heavily impact croplands and will lead to a decrease in agricultural productivity, as well as concerns over food security. (IPCC, 2022).

Across the LAC countries there has been a significant decrease in soil moisture on croplands over the last four decades (by around 2.5%). The countries most affected include Argentina, Paraguay, and Brazil, which experienced a decline of more than 8.6%, 7.7%, and 5.8%. In the case of the Caribbean countries, it has fallen by 3.1% (Figure 18).

Wildfires are an increasing problem for the LAC region. The forested area potentially exposed to wildfires is very large (32%), presenting an imminent risk to populations and ecosystems. In some countries such as Jamaica, Paraguay, Mexico and El Salvador, over 70% of the forested area is exposed to wildfires. While the shares are smaller in Brazil and Venezuela (46% and 40% respectively), due to the size of these countries they represent over 2.2 million km
, an area larger than the size of Mexico (Figure 19).

Climate change also exacerbate storms, which not only lead to the loss of human life, but can destroy economic infrastructure, increasing the costs of loss and damage, as well as future replacement and construction.

Tropical cyclones are limited to a subset of LAC countries due to their geographic position. In the Caribbean, almost all countries are exposed to tropical cyclones. Belize and Mexico also are heavily affected, with more than 50% of their populations and built-up areas exposed to extreme tropical cyclones.
Extreme cyclone are defined as those that occur in a period of 100 years
Exposure to cyclones of category 1 or higher on the Saffir-Simpson scale with a return period of 100 years, 2020

Note: Category 1 cyclones on the Saffir-Simpson scale are described as ‘very dangerous winds that will produce some damage’, thus being considered a cyclone. Higher categories cover extensive, devastating and catastrophic damage respectively.
Source: Maes, M., et al. (2022), “Monitoring exposure to climate-related hazards: Indicator methodology and key results”, OECD Environment Working Papers, No. 201, OECD Publishing, Paris,

River flooding is a climate-related hazard that has generated increasing concern. The recent floods in Pakistan in September 2022 were dramatic, affecting at least two-thirds of the country, displacing 33 million people, and causing more than 1200 causalities (Mallapaty, 2022[47]). These events are a reminder of how river flooding can affect people’s lives directly and cause substantial economic losses by damaging infrastructure, settlements, and agricultural lands. Due to the type of ecosystem and the location of most populations, river flooding is not a major concern. Nevertheless, it is estimated that on average, 5% of the population is affected in the LAC region. This varies across the subregions, with South American, Central American and the Caribbean countries having, respectively 11.9%, 3.3%, and 0.1% of their population exposed. The countries most affected are Suriname and Guyana, with 67% and 23% of the population exposed (Figures 21 and 22)

Natural climate variability and human-caused climate change increase risks attributed to climate-related hazards, influencing the frequency, intensity, extent and duration of extreme weather and climate events. Climate-related hazard, exposure and vulnerability are key dimensions of disaster risk. Measuring all dimensions that encompass risk is difficult because of data limitations, particularly on a global scale. For example, there are no commonly used data sources for assessing vulnerability globally.

The indicators presented are a selection of a broader set of indicators observed climate-related hazards developed by Maes et al. (2022) the indicators are on data from a number of official sources such as the Copernicus Climate Data Store (CDS), the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) and the Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency (JAXA), among others. For a detailed discussion see Maes et al. (2022). All regional averages presented here are simple, non-weighted averages over the countries in the LAC region. They therefore do not consider differences in area or population and represent the exposure of an average LAC country to natural hazards, but not the actual share of land or population of the region that is exposed.
Extreme cyclone are defined as those that occur in a period of 100 years
